title: Neurosarcoidosis
icd10: G53 (Cranial nerve disorders in diseases classified elsewhere)
scope: ** Diagnostic workup and management of suspected or confirmed neurosarcoidosis across all neurological presentations: cranial neuropathies, aseptic meningitis, hypothalamic-pituitary dysfunction, myelopathy, peripheral neuropathy, hydrocephalus, and mass lesions. Covers Zajicek diagnostic criteria (definite, probable, possible), acute immunotherapy, steroid-sparing agents, and long-term immunosuppression. For isolated pulmonary or systemic sarcoidosis without neurological involvement, defer to pulmonology. For other granulomatous CNS diseases (e.g., granulomatosis with polyangiitis, TB meningitis), use respective templates.

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology (neuroimmunology/neurosarcoidosis specialist) for diagnosis confirmation, immunotherapy guidance, and long-term management
Pulmonology for pulmonary sarcoidosis staging, PFTs, and bronchoscopy/EBUS biopsy coordination
Ophthalmology for comprehensive eye examination including slit lamp (uveitis screen), visual acuity, OCT, and visual fields
Endocrinology for hypothalamic-pituitary axis evaluation and hormonal replacement management if pituitary involvement documented
Rheumatology for systemic sarcoidosis co-management and steroid-sparing immunosuppression coordination
Neurosurgery for VP shunt placement if obstructive hydrocephalus, or for meningeal/brain biopsy if tissue diagnosis required
Interventional pulmonology for EBUS-guided lymph node biopsy to confirm systemic sarcoidosis diagnosis
Cardiology for cardiac MRI interpretation and management if cardiac sarcoidosis suspected (conduction abnormalities, cardiomyopathy)
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, and fall prevention given myelopathy or peripheral neuropathy
Occupational therapy for ADL adaptation and energy conservation given fatigue and functional impairment
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation given cranial nerve involvement (CN IX, X) and cognitive-linguistic rehabilitation
Neuropsychology for cognitive assessment and rehabilitation planning given neurocognitive impairment
Pain management for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line agents
Social work for insurance navigation, disability resources, and long-term care planning
Dermatology for skin biopsy if cutaneous lesions present (erythema nodosum, lupus pernio, papules, plaques) as accessible biopsy site
Infusion center coordination for IV methylprednisolone, infliximab, rituximab, or cyclophosphamide infusions
Fertility specialist for reproductive counseling before initiating teratogenic immunosuppressants (methotrexate, mycophenolate, cyclophosphamide)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately for sudden vision loss, new weakness, difficulty walking, severe headache, seizures, or difficulty breathing (may indicate disease progression or complications)
Neurosarcoidosis is a chronic, treatable condition -- improvement may be gradual over weeks to months with appropriate immunotherapy
Do NOT stop corticosteroids abruptly as this may cause adrenal crisis and disease flare; always taper under physician supervision
Report signs of infection immediately (fever >100.4F, cough, dysuria, rash, wound redness) as immunosuppressive therapy increases infection risk
Avoid live vaccines while on immunosuppressive therapy (inform all physicians and pharmacists of immunosuppression status)
Monitor blood sugars if diabetic or if on corticosteroids -- steroids significantly elevate blood glucose
Do not drive until cleared by neurology if visual impairment, seizures, or significant neurological deficits are present
Keep a symptom diary tracking visual changes, weakness, numbness, headaches, fatigue, and pain to monitor treatment response
Take methotrexate on the same day each week; take folic acid daily EXCEPT on methotrexate day to reduce side effects
Report excessive thirst or urination (may indicate diabetes insipidus from hypothalamic involvement requiring treatment adjustment)
Pregnancy must be avoided during methotrexate, mycophenolate, or cyclophosphamide therapy; discuss contraception with neurology and OB/GYN
Attend all follow-up appointments -- neurosarcoidosis requires regular monitoring with MRI, labs, and clinical assessments
Wear medical alert identification (bracelet/card) indicating neurosarcoidosis, immunosuppressive medications, and adrenal insufficiency if applicable
Sun protection is important while on methotrexate and immunosuppressive therapy due to increased skin cancer risk

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to improve pulmonary function and reduce infection risk during immunosuppression
Alcohol avoidance or strict limitation while on methotrexate due to additive hepatotoxicity
Low-sodium diet to reduce fluid retention and hypertension from corticosteroid therapy
Calcium-rich diet (dairy, leafy greens) for bone protection during chronic steroid use; AVOID excessive vitamin D supplementation unless calcium is normal
Regular weight-bearing exercise as tolerated (walking, resistance training) to prevent steroid-related osteoporosis and deconditioning
Adequate hydration (2-3 L/day) especially if on methotrexate or if hypercalciuria present to prevent nephrolithiasis
Fall prevention measures at home (remove loose rugs, adequate lighting, grab bars in bathroom) given myelopathy and balance impairment
Stress management and adequate sleep (7-8 hours nightly) as stress may exacerbate symptoms and fatigue
Vaccinations should be up to date before initiating immunosuppressive therapy (especially pneumococcal, influenza, hepatitis B); avoid live vaccines on immunosuppression
Sun protection (SPF 50+, protective clothing) during immunosuppressive therapy due to increased skin cancer risk
Energy conservation techniques (pacing activities, scheduled rest periods) to manage sarcoidosis-related fatigue
Annual ophthalmologic examination even if asymptomatic due to risk of subclinical uveitis and steroid-related cataracts/glaucoma

differential.features: Subacute meningitis; basilar meningeal enhancement; caseating granulomas; CSF low glucose, high protein, elevated ADA; risk factors (endemic areas, immunosuppression)
differential.tests: AFB culture/smear; CSF TB PCR (GeneXpert); QuantiFERON-TB; chest CT (apical disease vs. hilar adenopathy); tissue biopsy (caseating vs. non-caseating)

differential.features: Progressive encephalopathy; periventricular enhancement; homogeneous enhancing mass; immunocompromised
differential.tests: CSF cytology/flow cytometry; brain biopsy; FDG-PET (intense uptake); HIV testing

differential.features: Relapsing-remitting course; periventricular/juxtacortical/infratentorial/spinal cord lesions (Dawson fingers); oligoclonal bands; young female predominance
differential.tests: MRI (MS vs. sarcoid pattern); CSF oligoclonal bands; no systemic involvement; no hilar adenopathy

differential.features: Optic neuritis and longitudinally extensive transverse myelitis; area postrema syndrome
differential.tests: AQP4-IgG (positive); no hilar adenopathy; different MRI pattern

differential.features: Headache; multifocal strokes; beading on angiography; CSF pleocytosis

differential.features: Sinusitis; pulmonary nodules/cavities; glomerulonephritis; pachymeningeal enhancement
differential.tests: c-ANCA (PR3); biopsy showing necrotizing vasculitis with granulomas; renal function

differential.features: Cranial neuropathy (CN VII bilateral); meningitis; radiculopathy; erythema migrans; endemic area
differential.tests: Lyme serology (two-tier); CSF Lyme antibody index; travel history

differential.features: Cranial neuropathies; meningitis; Argyll Robertson pupils; cognitive decline; positive serology
differential.tests: RPR/VDRL; CSF VDRL; FTA-ABS; HIV co-testing

differential.features: Chronic meningitis; basilar enhancement; endemic area; immunocompromised
differential.tests: Fungal cultures; Histoplasma/Coccidioides antigen; CSF antibodies; biopsy

differential.features: Known malignancy; cranial neuropathies; headache; progressive; CSF cytology positive
differential.tests: CSF cytology (serial LPs increase yield); MRI (nodular leptomeningeal enhancement); whole-body staging

differential.features: Mass-forming lesions; pachymeningeal or orbital involvement; elevated serum IgG4; multi-organ fibrosis
differential.tests: Serum IgG4 level; tissue biopsy (storiform fibrosis, IgG4+ plasma cells >40%); no non-caseating granulomas

differential.features: Hypothalamic-pituitary involvement; orbital masses; bone lesions; skin involvement
differential.tests: Tissue biopsy (CD68+ foamy histiocytes in ECD; CD1a+/Langerin+ in LCH); BRAF V600E mutation; PET/CT

differential.features: Pulmonary nodules; CNS involvement; EBV-associated; angiocentric lymphoid proliferation
differential.tests: Lung biopsy; EBV in-situ hybridization; angiocentric/angiodestructive pattern

differential.features: Oral/genital ulcers; brainstem involvement; CSF neutrophilic pleocytosis; pathergy test
differential.tests: Clinical criteria; pathergy test; HLA-B51; no hilar adenopathy

differential.features: Persistent CSF pleocytosis and meningeal enhancement without identifiable cause after exhaustive workup
differential.tests: Comprehensive infectious, inflammatory, and neoplastic workup; brain/meningeal biopsy if refractory

Desmopressin titration; fluid balance adjustment

If hypercalcemia: IV normal saline hydration; hold vitamin D; consider calcitonin
Adjust renally-dosed medications; hydration

disposition.criteria: Stable or improving neurological exam; able to perform basic ADLs; seizure-free (if applicable); diabetes insipidus well-controlled on desmopressin; oral medications tolerated; steroid taper plan established; follow-up with neurology within 1-2 weeks; outpatient labs and imaging scheduled; family/caregiver education completed

New-onset or worsening neurosarcoidosis requiring IV methylprednisolone; diagnostic workup requiring expedited imaging and LP; new cranial neuropathy with visual threat; new seizures requiring medication optimization; diabetes insipidus requiring titration; need for tissue biopsy coordination

Acute hydrocephalus requiring EVD/VP shunt; severe elevated ICP; status epilepticus; severe myelopathy with respiratory compromise; rapid neurological decline; autonomic instability; severe hyponatremia or hypercalcemia requiring close monitoring
Neurosurgery not available (hydrocephalus, biopsy); neuroimmunology specialist not available; interventional pulmonology for EBUS biopsy; infusion center for biologic therapy not available
Significant functional deficits from myelopathy or multifocal disease; medically stable; expected to benefit from intensive PT/OT/ST; unable to safely return home

All discharged patients: neurology follow-up within 1-2 weeks; ophthalmology within 2-4 weeks; pulmonology if pulmonary involvement; endocrinology if pituitary involvement; labs per monitoring schedule; MRI per protocol
New or worsening neurological symptoms (vision loss, weakness, seizures); infection on immunosuppression; suspected relapse; uncontrolled diabetes insipidus; severe steroid side effects
